title.narrative: Training on Third Gender's rights

description.narrative:
This tailor-made training can help us to improve the competencies and skills of our staff and relevant stakeholders in the following fields and subjects:
- improve the skills of the staff on how to conduct qualitative research and collect validated data;
- improve the knowhow and skills of the staff to set up an awareness campaign
- improve the essential skills of the staff on how to defectively communicate with political parties, Ulema’s and juridical about the issues related to third gender and their right (socio- and economical).
- improve the knowhow of the staff members on third gender in relation to international human rights and sharia law
- aware and increase the understanding of the staff on best practices and approaches implemented in other Islamic countries in relation to third gender right, conditions; medically and psychologically.

participating-org.narrative: Hamida Barmaki Organization for the Rule of Law

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Developing policy Guideline on third gender
Human Rights on Third Gender in Afghanistan
Peacebuilding Training
Strategy review and implementation of HBORL
Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: DO NOT USE Labour market and entrepreneurship

description.narrative:
**(if applicable)** Describe the progress that is made in strengthening the capacity of the requesting organisation to deliver the products and services which are demanded by the labour market and society in general? Has competitiveness / efficiency been improved?
In case the requesting organisation is an education institution, what are the prospects of graduates to find employment or to become self-employed? Has the training had an impact on sectoral development?

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
All the trainings and workshops have been evaluated through evaluation forms and meetings with participants. The requesting organisation have revealed their gratitude for the trainings we provided. It enabled the requesting organisation to tackle their capacity needs in third gender. In addition, the requesting organisation received training in strategic planning (which was not part of this training). This was much appreciated by the requesting organisation as this enabled them to integrate the gained knowledge within their organisation.
Through this training the requesting organisation was enabled to establish - for the first time in Afghanistan- a task force to promote justice for the third gender in Afghanistan. Most importantly through this training the requesting organisation was able to involve the key stakeholders to work towards an equal society for all!
We as Dutch provider are proud and happy to jointly deploy this valuable project. Our cooperation with HBORL is sustained as we have developed a 5-year proposal to develop policies and laws to promote justice for the third gender in Afghanistan.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
### Training: Human rights on third gender in Afghanistan
- This training enabled participants to promote human rights values in initiating/programming for Third Gender activities in Afghanistan leading by civil society in the coordination of relevant state institutions, the national human rights and academic institutions.
- This training established a task force (TF) on LGBT human rights promotion in Afghanistan. The TF members are Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission, Police Human Rights Division, Dunia University, Parliament, Ministry of Justice civil rights Division, General Prosecution Office and Civil Society. The Secretariat of the task force is coordinated by HBORL.
- The participants have gained right set of skills and knowledge to promote justice for the third gender in Afghanistan. Hence the participants gained knowhow to start the law development process for the third gender.
### Workshops on peacebuilding, strategy development and policy guideline for third gender:
_Strengthen HBROL as a peacebuilding civil society institution through a workshop on peace and conflict resolution and partnership with stakeholders._
o HBROL key staff have gained the capacity for sustainable peace
o Key stakeholders in peace promotion can build on peacemaking methods in collaboration with civil society and human rights actors in Afghanistan.
o A sample of recommendations by the workshop has been developed for HPC
o A selection of recommendations by the workshop has been developed for SMP
o Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission has gained the capacity for sustainable peace and conflict resolution based on human rights and social justice approaches.
_Reviewed and updated HBROL strategy based on the new projects, gained knowledge and key result areas_
o HBROL strategy has been reviewed and updated
o HBROL staff understand and know the method of using the strategy
o HBROL staff have learned how to review and update the strategy independently
_Developed a policy guideline for main stakeholders to support people with a third gender in Afghanistan._
o A secretariat for the promotion of human rights of people of the third gender has been established
o A policy paper for the promotion of human rights of people of the third gender has been developed

comment.narrative: 12-08-2021: In each training the gender balans has been respected. The number of Women participants have been 6 out of 11 participants.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 12-08-2021: The entire training focussed on the improvement of laws for the third gender community in Afghanistan.

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 12-08-2021: The participants received training in an interactive manner. They have acquired skills and know how in effective communication. In addition, the particiants were trained on how to provide follow-up trainings. Also here they learned to communicate effectively.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value:
This training focused on gender equality for all: men, women and third genders. The training enabled participants in theoretical knowledge such as:
- Human Rights as a basic approach for working on gender equality and other kinds of Gender rights-based passageway.
- The notion of gender equality
- LGBT concept and regulations
- Police and LGBT
- Jogjakarta Principles
The participants were enabled to put this gained knowledge in a policy guideline and share it with relevant organisations to use in their workplace. In addition to this the participants are affiliated with different organisations such as: Parliament (House of Meshrano Jerga Secretariat) Ministry for Interior Affairs MoIA (Director of Human Rights and Women Afghans), Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission AIHRC (Women Rights Commissioner), Academia (Associated professor of Dunia University), Chairwomen of Hamida Barmaky Rule of Law Organisation (HBRLO) Board and civil society (HBROL Secretariat). The participants have key positions within these organisations and they were assigned to integrate the gained knowledge into their own organisation.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value: We provided several trainings: Human Rights for the third gender, peacebuilding, policy guideline for the third gender and strategic development for the organisation. In each of these trainings the participants acquired skills, knowhow and also assigned to share this acquired skills with other staff members and partner organisations.
